It was seven days and seven nights before the king recovered, and he awoke to a miracle. Once more birds were trilling in the trees, the clocks chimed and waves roared. Once more the world had music. And his favourite wife of all stood over him and smiled, and in the timbre of her lilting voice he felt once again that she loved him. The people were in celebration, singing in the streets whatever tunes would come into their heads. And they sang until their throats turned red raw. They sang until their arteries burst and gushed. They screamed their new songs of pain. The king watched in horror as the birds fell dead in the street, as the waves struggled limply and then were drowned by the seas beneath them. He heard his infant son cry out his last, his face bitten off by a savage lullaby. The lilting voice of his wife, that he had loved so much, grinned at him cruelly before wrapping itself around her throat and throttling her silent. The music raced through the kingdom, sparing none its terrible beauty. As the bodies of his subjects fell to the ground, their death rattle sounded like the rhythm of a perfect drum. And the music at last came for the king. 'Why?' he asked. ‘Because we have been to the outside world,’ the music replied. 'We have seen the infinite darkness, and we have learned that we need not only inspire love but fear.’ And with a sound of brass and strings so beautiful it stopped the king's heart, the music swallowed him up whole, and became the new and dreadful lord of the entire world.
Sounds like the closing phrase of the Beatles' A Day in the Life.
What have we done?
Hold on!
I can't. It's too much. Doctor, there's too much sound!
Silence.
What happened?
I just hope I've done the right thing. You all right, Charley?
Am I all right? You're the one with your throat slit. How is it possible you're still able to talk?

It wants talk. It wants noise. As much as it can get. It hasn't severed my vocal chords at all. Indeed, if anything, it's trying to protect them, polish them, put a nice sheen on them. They might be exposed at the moment and flapping out of a gash in my neck
Yes, it's really rather horrible.
But just at the moment, I suspect they're in as pristine a condition as I could ever hope for.
I don't believe it. There's not even a trace of blood.

The creature isn't interested in blood, only in the sounds we produce. It's all it ever wanted. Every time it needed to feed, it tried to take what it could from us, induced heightened emotional states so our noises would be the more interesting. And when that wasn't enough, it had to go deeper. It must have recognised the tastiest sounds of all came from our vocal chords.
But how could it know that?
Well, how does a baby know which part of it's mother produces milk? An inbuilt survival instinct. Life will always find a way.
So these past weeks, each time this creature has attacked us, we've just been breast-feeding it?
Exactly. And when it caused pain, well, the baby doesn't know how hard it bites, does it? I don't think it ever wanted to hurt us. On the contrary, it needed us alive. We are its
parents, after all.
So when you made me slit your throat?
It needs to feed in order to grow, and I wanted to glut it.
Clever.
Yes, I thought so.
Just one thing.
Which is?
Do we want this creature to grow?

I don't think we had much choice. Either a piecemeal snack provider now and again as we walk around in circles for years, or give it a banquet. Turn the child into an adult and see if it can be reasoned with.
And if it can't?
I had rather been worrying about that myself. The forced acceleration could have made it quite insane.
Quiet, isn't it?
Squelching sounds. Charley gasps.
Doctor!
The mammal is falling apart.
Her face, my face, it's collapsing in on itself. No!
Turning to bone, bone to ashes, ashes to dust, dust to the very air we breathe.
Why is the sound creature doing that to it?
It isn't. Oh dear, I hadn't thought of this.
What?
It's been out-evolved.
What do you mean, out-evolved?

There isn't much time for explanations, but you know that evolution is about the constant development of living beings? Well, what happens if a creature can't keep up the pace, doesn't evolve as fast as the others?
It dies out.
Yes. I've got a very bad feeling about this.
Doctor, my hand! I can't move my hand! Turning to stone.
It's started.
I'm crumbling away. Doctor!
It's happening to me, too. We're being left behind. We're now as dinosaurs to modern man.
We're dying out? What do we do? Doctor!
Come closer. That's it. We have to evolve as well, see if we can catch it up.
Evolve? How?
Well, all this time, we've been slowing turning into one another. We'll have to complete the process. Come closer still. Press your body against mine.
Squelch.
I'll have to become part of you.
Each part of each other. Evolution or extinction, it's the only way forward. Either the sound creature becomes the more developed, or we do.
I'm not sure I can do that.
Don't be frightened, Charley.
Give up who I am, even for you?
No, but I'll give up myself for you, Charley. Step into me, and I'll step into you.
I won't be frightened. Every part of me changing, becoming you.
No more talking. Sound is the medium of our enemy.
Yes.
Put your mouth against mine and press hard, so that our faces become locked together.
Squidge, squelch!
And a new creature is born.
Doctor, where are you?
It's all right, Charley.
I can't see you.
All around you. You're safe in here.
No, it's too much. I'm losing myself, drowning.
Hold on, Charley. Just hold on.
(distant) I can't. Ah!
Charley! Charley, come back! Charley!
Birdsong and the slow ticking of a clock.
Where am I? This is like the drawing room in my parent's house.
Door creaks open.
Who are you? Come closer. Come closer, I can't see you properly.
Heavy footsteps.
Are you all right?
Doctor, is that you?
You summoned me, Mama.
Did I? I don't remember. Wait a moment, what did you call me?
I called you Mama, Mama.
I see. Don't you think that's a rather odd thing to do?
Not at all. You like being called Mama. It reminds you constantly that you're a mother, and you like being a mother.
Yes, a mother.
Being a mother is all you ever wanted.
And I take it you're my son, then.
Your daughter, Charlotte.
Charley.
No, Mama. Charlie is a boy's name, and you expressly wanted a daughter.
I did?

Oh, yes. When you first gave birth, out popped a boy, and you took one look and said 'no, it's not a son I want. Not a son.' And you pushed him right back inside, and you said, ‘don't’ you even think about coming out again until you're a daughter. It's a daughter I want.' And you only let me out when I'd become the daughter you needed.
And what do I need a daughter for? Why is that so important to me?
Silly, silly Mama. You can't give your brooch to a son, now can you?
The brooch. Yes, it's your sixteenth birthday, isn't it, Charlotte?
It is. I'm all grown up now.
Happy birthday.
Happy birthday indeed. Happy birthday to me. I want the brooch. The one your mother gave you, and her mother gave to her.
Tradition.
Exactly. The parent passes on to the child, makes way for the child, on and on for evermore. And I am your child, Mama. And it's time you made way for me, don't you think?
Here you are.
Thank you, Mama.
You are no longer a child. You are an adult.
I know. And I shall enjoy my maturity.
The brooch is a little crusted with blood.
That doesn't matter. I shall treasure it. Let me give you a kiss.
Kiss.
And now, Mama, dearest Mama, who gave me life, who gave me everything, I think it's time that you left.
Oh, so soon?
I think so. Look at yourself. You're an old woman now, getting older and older by the second. But you needn't be afraid. You will live on through me.
Well, that's all right, then.
The parent lives on through the child. Years of evolution. Children becoming parents giving birth to children. Each time the child becoming stronger, more perfect. Your job is done. You can rest now.
I've been out-evolved.
Exactly. And much as I love you, Mama, that makes you something of an embarrassment.
It's time I died, then.
If you wouldn't mind. Only one creature can be at the top of the evolutionary ladder, and it seems it's me.
A daughter. I've had a daughter after all, and I'm so proud.
I'm the best daughter who ever lived.
You're a very beautiful woman. Did I once look like that?
Perhaps. Who knows?
The brooch will look beautiful on you too, when you wear it.
Wear it? Is that what you do with it?
What did you think the brooch is for?
To hand to my daughter, to keep tradition, to keep evolution alive.
No, a brooch is for wearing to formal dinners and informal banquets.
Fancy that.
It can also be used as a knife. Good for slicing up pieces of alien meat or doing the odd hasty dissection.
There's more to this brooch business than meets the eye.
It's not just a symbol. You've got it wrong. Give it back to me.
But it's mine. I'm all grown up. I'm an adult now.
A girl who isn't old enough to know what a brooch is for, isn't old enough to wear a brooch. Give it back to me, child. It's not yours yet.
Not fair. You were going to die for me. You said you'd die for me.
I'm not ready to die yet. I'm Charley Pollard, the original model. I have no
daughter. I will never have a daughter.
Not fair. Not fair.
Loud noise.
Enough of that. Now get to your room right now without any supper, whilst I decide what to do with you.
Shan't. I shall go and find Papa. I know he'll let me live. I Know he'll die for me.
The Tardis! I've got the Tardis back. She's all here, aren't you, old girl. Back to normal.
Console controls beep.
I can go anywhere. Time, space, all at my fingertips. I have the entire universe to explore.
Whoosh.
Aren't you forgetting something though, Doctor?
Er, possibly. I often forget things.
You had agreed to sacrifice yourself for the universe, remember? You offered your life to save everything?
Yes, I dare say I did.
Giving up the world you know, every world you ever knew, just so that they could go on without you. No, more than that, am I right? There was another motive, wasn't there?
You tell me. You seem to have all the answers.
So that Charley could go on without you. Am I right? You'd die for the universe? But we don't even have to go that far, do we? You'd die for her. Me, I should say.
There are many friends that I have cared for, deeply cared for, that I would do anything to protect.
Your memento mori.
No. Yes. Perhaps.
You gave up everything for Charley, didn't you, Doctor?
I gave up everything for the universe.
A universe with Charley Pollard in, yes?
A universe capable of producing a Charley Pollard. Well, let's just say I was in a very generous mood.
And I'm grateful. Thank you, Doctor, very much.
Yes, well.

Very, very, very, very much. When you came here, you thought your life would be snuffed out in an instant. You almost wanted it. The ultimate act of heroism. You are a hero, aren't you? Dying for billions upon billions of worlds. Dying for one single little girl. But, well, I hardly like to point it out, but you are still here, hanging about. Existing, quite frankly. Don't you think you should get on with the whole dying bit?
You're not Charley. You know I know that.
Yes, but you can call me Charley if you like. I'm your child. You can call me whatever you see fit.
You sound like Charley, but you don't look like her though.
No?
Just a curious mix of limbs and flesh.
I'm an amalgam of all those who've travelled with you. Those for whom you would have given your life. Your memento mori.
You're the sound creature.
If that's what you want to call me, Daddy. Though it's not the most affectionate of names.
How did you get inside my head?
Well, through the ear, naturally.
Yes, I suppose it would have been.
I can't tell you what a relief it is to assemble all the sounds you speak and make some sense of them at last. If only so I have the words to say thank you.
Oh, believe me, you've no reason to thank me.

But of course I have. For giving me life. For giving me a fighting chance at survival. I won't disappoint you, Daddy. I know there are lots of factors which can weigh against the success of a new lifeform, but I'll dig my heels in and not give up.
Ah. I've been wanting to talk to you about that.
And thank you too for being prepared to die, so that I can go on in your place. Survival of the fittest, and all that.
And that's another matter on my er, to discuss list. Listen to me. Your birth, it was an accident. Your creation wiped out a race that ought to have survived instead. It was their world, not yours.
That's not my fault.
No, it isn't about fault.
And you shouldn't be here either.
No.
So the situation remains. We are both here, and only one of us can go on. Why should it be you rather than me?
That's a good point. However, I'm afraid I've really rather decided it is going to be me.
That complicates things a bit.
Well, I'm sorry about that.
But I'm not worried. You'll agree to die for me, sooner or later.
You know, I really wouldn't count on it.
But you must! After all, you were prepared to die for an entire universe, weren't you? Weren't you?
Yes.
You'd die so she could go on.
Charley.
Exactly. And she's not even family, is she, Daddy. Come on, it's the same choice. You've already made it once before.
It's not the same choice.
Yes, it is. Would you be prepared to sacrifice everything for Charley's sake? Because if you are, if life means so little to you, you can hardly defeat me, to whom life is everything.
You're right. It is the same.

Only one of us can survive, and it'll be the one who'll grip onto life the most ferociously. And I will never give it up. Not ever. Never, never, never. Whereas you're putting yours into jeopardy at the slightest whim. You'd die for everybody, wouldn't you, Doctor? You'd die for anybody.
No. Not anybody.
For Charley.
I don't know.
Would you die for the universe? Would you die for Charley?
I don't know.
Make the choice again, one final time.
I can't. I tell you, I don't know.

It won't hurt you. Just agree to die, and you will slowly fade away. Come on. By coming here in the first place you were already resigned to death. Now choose to die once more. Die for the universe. Die for your past companions you befriended, protected, loved then discarded. Die for Charley, and die for me.
The Tardis, she's gone.
The voice is both the Doctor and Charley.
Yes, Daddy. You and I are all alone now.
Not quite all alone.
Charley.
Keep out of this. It is his decision to make.
Yes, my decision.
So make it. Would you die again?
All that I've seen, a thousand years of life, a life time of exploring an entire universe. The sights, smells, taste, all taken from me. All of it reduced to fading memory.
Would you die again?
But all of it, it would be nothing, worth nothing to me, if I couldn't let it go for the sake of one life. For the sake of a life which deserves life.
Would you die again?
I love Charley. I don't quite know what that means. I don't know whether it's strength or weakness or insanity, but I love her.
Would you die again for her?
For Charley, yes. I'd do it every time.
Doctor!
After all, what would I be without her now?
Oh, Doctor, I'm sorry.
You would die?
Yes.
You would die so another might live?
Yes.
You would die so I might live?
Yes.
No!
I'm sorry, Charley.
But it's not the same thing. Dying for me and dying for this music thing
But it is. Survival is a matter of staying alive, no matter what. The music creature would never give up like I would, so it is the strongest.
Survival of the fittest.
But I haven't agreed.
What, Charley?
I am part of the Doctor's body too, now, and I thank him for giving everything up for me. Thank you, Doctor. Thank you for that strength. But I have my own strength too, and I refuse.
What?
You refuse, Charley? You'd do that for me?
I do not accept your sacrifice. Not this time.
No! You can't!
Let her burn in the R101. Let her be executed by the Time Lords. Live on. With regret, but live on.
No!
Right or wrong, whatever happens to Charley Pollard, I choose the Doctor to live.
Multitonal scream.
Please, Mummy, please. I am your daughter!
No. I will never have a daughter. That is a life closed to me now.
I am your daughter. Give me your brooch so I can go on.
I'll give my brooch, but not to you. To the Doctor.
Are you sure?
Take it. I am prepared to die so that you can live.
No!
Yes! And I'm prepared to die too, but only so that you, Charley, can live.
But what about me? What about me?
Sorry. There's no room for a gooseberry.
Daddy, I beg you.
I can't help you.
But it isn't fair.
No, it isn't. I'm sorry.
Long drawn-out scream that ends in a single high note sung by a soprano.
(distant) Help me. Help me. Help me. Help.
(sighs) Is the music dead?
No. Merely silenced.
Yes.
We could kill it if you want. Do you want that?
Do we have to?
No. But we could do it. We could destroy all sound if we wanted.
Can you get us back to the way we were before?
Why would you want that?
What?
Charley, we could go on. We could evolve further, see where that takes us.
What would be the good of that?
The good of it? Why, that's just it. It wouldn't have to be good or bad. We could set the limits on goodness.
Doctor, I don't understand.

You see, this could be just a new beginning. We could press forward, keep on improving, lose all the defects and frailties which held us back. We could lord over Kromon, we could be greater than the Censor, more powerful even than Koth.
What are these things? What are you talking about?

I don't know what they are, but it doesn't matter. We don't need to know anything when we can be everything. Explore this new universe. Why do that when we could become the new universe, evolve onwards and upwards for evermore.
Can you get us out of here?
I can crack open this glass prison like an eggshell. See?
Crash!
Charley, we can crack this world open.
But I don't want that. I want the Doctor and Charley back again. I want the Doctor.
The Doctor? That self-sacrificing fool? I could be better than that. We could be better.
But that's who I want. That's who I need. The man who had everything, and yet would give it up for something as small as me.
And now we have everything again.
I don't want everything. I want you. I want the Doctor.
I don't want to be without you, Charley.
You won't be.
I need you. I can't be on my own again.
Let me go. Set us free. You won't be alone, I promise you.
Yes. The Doctor and Charley. As it always was. Push away from me.
There's nothing to push against.
Push against my mind.
Squelching noise.
That's it, Charley. You're doing it.
The squelching stops. Charley is breathing heavily.
I'm whole again. My hands. I can move my hands. Doctor, we're back!
Thank you, Charley. Thank you for saving me.
I promise. I need you too.
You will always be a part of me now, inside, and I will always be a part of you.
I know. I'm glad.
Here, your brooch.
Thank you, but I don't need it any more.
Clatter.
That life is over now, isn't it.
Yes, I'm afraid so.
Don't be. That's quite a hole you punched in the glass wall. We can leave.

Remember, we were kept alive in here deliberately, but out there it's a different story. We're trapped here, on this one planet, without the Tardis. Lost in a new universe. We can't know what it's like.
I'm ready to find out if you are.
Yes.
Come on, take my hand.
But we can see now. We don't need to hold on to each other.
I know. Take my hand anyway.
Footsteps. A wind blows stronger and stronger.
